history.content:
I think you need more of a basic grounding in probability theory (for which 70 should be sufficient) and not much of linear algebra for 126. It is EECS 127 that assumes a solid understanding of linear algebra (which can be attained through strong performance in Math 54/EE16AB or Math 110).

Though, I would like to warn you that 61c, 168 and 126 in the Fall would be an extremely heavy courseload and I wanted to let you know this as you remarked you did not want to be overwhelmed. Probably switch 168 for a lighter tech/breadth maybe?

children.subject:
I am not sure why 168 is thought to be light. When I took it last fall with Shenker, I found it to be similar to 161, which is a moderate workload class, according to me. The projects in 168 are somewhat tedious and take up a lot of time actually (because they somehow seem to be disparate from the lectures) and also require mastery of Python. Again, this is just my opinion.

About 188 being on edX, see @6654 for some good advice. In general, 188 isn't as straightforward as people may think due to its notoriously hard tests; so even though it may not seem as challenging, it is actually quite difficult to get a good grade.

Honestly, considering your situation, don't go for another CS class as pretty much none of them are "light" (lol), they might just be lighter in comparison to other CS classes but still demand notable effort.
Thanks for that answer, really helpful. Isn't 168 the lightest tech aside from 188? I don't want to take 188 since it's an edX course.

history.content:
I've taken CS 70 and EE 16A, and did decent in both.

I'd like to take CS 189 and thus EECS 126 to prepare. I have not taken Math 110, Math 54, or any other probability course aside from CS 100.

Would taking EECS 126 in Fall and CS 189 the following semester be a mistake? I'm focused on learning, not getting an A, but I also don't want to be overwhelmed.

Fall:
61c
168?
X

Spring:
162
189
X
history.subject: EECS 126 with poor Linear Algebra and Probability Skills?
